elements.title: Authority Credential Stack: Front-Load Legitimacy Signals
elements.problem: Professional hosts (brokers, property managers) enter discovery with high skepticism because Split Lease is unknown. Jessica spent the first 3 minutes interrogating the business model ('Do you work with management companies?', 'I did look up split lease yesterday') because Robert's opening provided no substance—just 'I work for Split Lease.' Without visible authority markers (licenses, known clients, verifiable track record), the host's System 1 defaults to defensive questioning. This consumes cognitive bandwidth that could be spent on economic evaluation. The current discovery touchpoint lacks an authority credential stack that pre-authorizes the conversation.
elements.solution: Front-load authority credentials in the information hierarchy so hosts verify legitimacy before engaging with the business model. Primary layer (first 3 seconds): 'Licensed real estate platform, 150+ properties across Manhattan/Brooklyn.' Secondary layer (next 10 seconds): Social proof from recognizable authorities ('Partners include [Management Company Name]', 'Featured in [Publication]'). Tertiary layer (if host clicks through): Dedicated broker partnership page with testimonials from other brokers, case studies with conversion data, FAQ addressing broker-specific concerns (fee structure, confidentiality, approval processes). On calls, agents open with credential-establishing language: 'I'm Robert with Split Lease. We're a licensed platform that's helped 200+ brokers place inventory this year.' The scan order is: credentials first, then model explanation, then business terms.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I did look up split lease yesterday.' Then immediately: 'Do you work with management companies or is it just individual landlords?'
evidence.insight: Jessica researched Split Lease independently before the call (authority verification behavior). Her first substantive question probes client base to assess legitimacy. She needs to see credentials before she'll trust the model explanation.

evidence.quote: Because their positions speak of superior access to information and power, it makes great sense to comply with the wishes of properly constituted authorities. It makes so much sense, in fact, that we often do so when it makes no sense at all.
evidence.insight: Cialdini: authority symbols trigger automatic compliance. Jessica is checking whether Split Lease is a 'properly constituted authority.' Without those symbols, she withholds compliance (commitment).

evidence.quote: Titles are simultaneously the most difficult and the easiest symbols of authority to acquire. To earn one normally takes years of work and achievement. Yet it is possible for somebody who has put in none of this effort to adopt the mere label and receive a kind of automatic deference.
evidence.insight: Split Lease should display credentials (licenses, certifications, partnerships) as authority symbols that trigger automatic deference, reducing hosts' need to conduct defensive due diligence.

evidence.quote: Authority Credential Verification at Discovery: 'Without visible authority markers, the host's default response is skepticism and defensive questioning. Jessica spent the first 3 minutes interrogating the business model.'
evidence.insight: Layer 1 identified the user goal: 'Quickly verify that Split Lease is legitimate before investing time.' Layer 2 translates this into information architecture: credentials must be the primary information layer, visible in first 3 seconds.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Authority credentials are PRIMARY information (first 3 seconds). Business model explanation is SECONDARY (next 30 seconds). Economic terms are TERTIARY (after trust is established). Never reverse this order—hosts won't engage with the model until they trust the messenger.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive credential disclosure: First, display baseline legitimacy (license, property count). If host engages (clicks, opens call), reveal social proof (known partners, testimonials). If host requests detail (asks questions, schedules meeting), provide full verification (case studies, broker testimonials, FAQ).
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 authority signals in primary layer (license + property count + one social proof element). More than 3 creates decision paralysis. Each signal must be verifiable in <5 seconds (host can Google the license number, recognize the partner name, or see the publication logo).
scan_order: 1st: Visual authority symbol (license badge, logo of recognized partner)
2nd: Quantified legitimacy ('150+ properties', '200+ brokers')
3rd: Social proof headline ('Featured in [Publication]' or 'Partners with [Company]')
4th: Model explanation (only after credentials establish trust)
exclude: Vague language like 'we work with anybody' when asked about client base—this undermines authority
Generic company descriptions without verifiable credentials
Business model details before authority is established—hosts won't process this information while they're still in defensive mode
Requests for commitment (send listings, schedule onboarding) before credentials are verified

elements.title: Economic Transparency Calculator: Show ROI Before Commitment
elements.problem: Professional hosts evaluate Split Lease through an economic lens: 'Will this yield competitive returns vs. my traditional revenue streams?' Jessica spent 6+ minutes (06:29-12:52) negotiating pricing because the economics were unclear. When Robert finally explained the markup model ('You give me the price, already marked up with your fee'), he used autonomy language to build trust but left Jessica without benchmarks. She doesn't know: (1) What markup percentage is typical? (2) How price-sensitive are guests? (3) How long does conversion take? Without this data, Jessica is pricing blind, risking either under-pricing (losing profit) or over-pricing (losing conversions). Cognitive load: she must simultaneously understand the model, calculate her economics, and compare to traditional broker fees—all without transparent data.
elements.solution: Provide an economic transparency calculator as the primary pricing information layer. Interactive tool: 'Enter your base rent → see estimated markup range that converts → see projected commission over 3/6/12 months.' Show conversion data: 'Listings priced at $X convert in Y days on average. Listings above $Z convert in 2x days.' Compare to traditional economics with concrete example: 'Traditional broker fee: 1 month rent upfront ($2,000). Split Lease model: $50/day markup over 6 months = $9,000 total commission. You earn 4.5x more, paid over time.' Provide 'recommended markup' based on property type, location, lease duration. Allow hosts to override, but give data-driven starting point. Information hierarchy: ROI comparison first (primary), markup calculator second (interactive), conversion data third (validation).

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'What's the price range?' Robert: '$1,450 or $1,500 a month.' Jessica: 'For Manhattan, it's very expensive. I could find something maybe for 2000 a studio for maybe 1900, 2000.'
evidence.insight: Jessica challenges Robert's pricing because she has superior market knowledge. Robert's lack of pricing transparency undermines his credibility. This dynamic wastes time and creates doubt about whether Split Lease understands the market.

evidence.quote: Robert: 'You give me the price, which is already marked up with your fee. I don't want to know how much you marked up.'
evidence.insight: Robert uses autonomy language to build trust, but this shifts all pricing risk to Jessica. If she prices wrong and doesn't convert, she'll blame the model. Providing benchmarks would reduce this risk.

evidence.quote: Because their positions speak of superior access to information and power, it makes great sense to comply with the wishes of properly constituted authorities.
evidence.insight: Split Lease should position itself as the pricing authority by sharing proprietary conversion data. 'We've processed 1,000+ bookings and know what pricing works' is an authority signal that makes hosts more likely to accept pricing guidance.

evidence.quote: Transparent Economics Before Commitment: 'Professional hosts evaluate Split Lease primarily through an economic lens. Without transparent data, Jessica is pricing blind, which increases risk of under-pricing or over-pricing.'
evidence.insight: Layer 1 identified the user goal: 'Understand exactly how much money I'll make before I invest time creating listings.' Layer 2 structures this as: ROI calculator as PRIMARY information, conversion data as SECONDARY validation.

elements.hierarchy_principle: ROI comparison is PRIMARY information (hosts must see '4.5x traditional broker fee' immediately). Markup calculator is SECONDARY (interactive tool, hosts input their data). Conversion benchmarks are TERTIARY (validation that the model works). Never hide pricing data behind 'contact us'—this signals lack of transparency.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate transparency: Show ROI comparison on evaluation page (before host commits to call). Calculator available without gating (no signup required). Conversion data displayed alongside calculator results. On calls, reference the calculator ('As you saw in the ROI tool...') rather than re-explaining from scratch.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 data points in primary ROI comparison (traditional broker fee, Split Lease commission, multiplier). Calculator limited to 3 inputs (base rent, lease duration, property type). Results displayed as simple comparison table, not complex charts. Time budget: host should model their economics in <2 minutes.
scan_order: 1st: ROI multiplier headline ('Earn 4.5x traditional broker fee')
2nd: Concrete example comparing traditional vs. Split Lease economics
3rd: Interactive calculator (host inputs their data)
4th: Conversion benchmarks (validation that pricing works)
exclude: 'Whatever you feel reasonable' as pricing guidance—autonomy without benchmarks creates risk
Withholding conversion data under assumption hosts will experiment—professional hosts need data upfront
Generic statements like 'competitive returns' without specific ROI comparison
Hiding pricing information behind 'schedule a call to discuss'—this signals lack of transparency and wastes call time

elements.title: Honest Constraint Feedback: Real-Time Pricing Guardrails
elements.problem: Robert built trust with Jessica by arguing against his own short-term interests: 'Pricing things out of the market would be no interest to anybody. Start with rooms or studios, try to go on the lower cost.' This honest constraint advice—telling Jessica her higher-priced inventory won't convert—built credibility and warmed the relationship. However, this pattern is agent-dependent (requires Robert's skill) and doesn't scale. Most hosts won't receive this honest feedback, leaving them to discover through failed conversions that their listings are mispriced. Information challenge: How do we systematize honest constraint feedback so every host receives it, not just those lucky enough to talk to a skilled agent?
elements.solution: Embed real-time constraint feedback as automated information layer during listing creation and performance monitoring. Primary layer (during listing creation): 'Properties in this area at this price typically convert in 30+ days. Reducing price by 15% cuts conversion time to 10 days.' Visual indicator: pricing slider with green zone (recommended), yellow zone (slower conversion), red zone (rarely converts). Secondary layer (7 days after listing goes live with no proposals): Proactive outreach email: 'Your listing hasn't received proposals yet. Based on our data, reducing daily rate from $X to $Y would increase visibility 3x. Here's why...' Tertiary layer (host dashboard): 'Recommended adjustments' panel showing exactly what changes (price, photos, description) would improve conversion likelihood, with data-driven rationale. Frame all feedback using 'arguing against our own interests' language: 'We want you to succeed, and that means sometimes telling you when a listing won't work as currently priced.'

evidence.quote: Robert: 'Please start with rooms or studios or one bedrooms. Try to go on the whatever law was cost... pricing things out of the market would be no interest to anybody.'
evidence.insight: Robert constrains Jessica's inventory choices by telling her high-priced Manhattan inventory won't convert. This is honest advice that argues against Split Lease's short-term interests (fewer listings to market) but builds long-term trust. Jessica accepts this constraint because it demonstrates Robert's expertise and goodwill.

evidence.source: cialdini-authority-liking-scarcity.txt, Vincent the waiter (referenced in journey-context.json)
evidence.quote: Vincent's maneuver... proved him to be a trustworthy informant, because he recommended dishes that were slightly less expensive than originally ordered.
evidence.insight: Vincent built trust by recommending cheaper dishes, arguing against the restaurant's short-term interests but maximizing customer satisfaction. Robert mirrors this by telling Jessica to send lower-cost inventory, which maximizes Jessica's conversion success.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I'll email you. You can expect to hear from me by Friday.' [Later:] 'That sounds good to me. Thank you so much, Robert.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's tone shifted from skeptical (01:01-03:00) to warm and committed (18:54-19:03) after Robert's honest constraint advice. She went from interrogating the model to thanking Robert warmly. This emotional shift signals relationship capital was built through honest guidance.

evidence.quote: Relationship Capital Through Honest Constraints: 'This pattern is agent-dependent and doesn't scale. Most hosts won't receive this honest, constraining advice, leaving them to discover through failed conversions that their inventory is mispriced.'
evidence.insight: Layer 1 identified the need to systematize honest feedback. Layer 2 translates this into information architecture: real-time constraint feedback must be a PRIMARY information layer during listing creation and a SECONDARY proactive layer after 7 days of low performance.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Real-time constraint feedback is PRIMARY information during listing creation (shown before host clicks 'publish listing'). Proactive performance feedback is SECONDARY (sent after 7 days of low engagement). Dashboard recommendations are TERTIARY (always-available reference). Never withhold constraint feedback—silence implies approval, hosts will interpret lack of guidance as validation.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate feedback: Show pricing guardrails during listing creation (green/yellow/red zones). Proactive outreach: If listing receives <5 views in 3 days or zero proposals in 7 days, send specific, data-driven recommendations. Persistent visibility: Dashboard 'Recommended adjustments' panel always visible, updated as market data changes.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1-2 constraint recommendations per interaction (price adjustment + one other factor like photos). Each recommendation must include: (1) specific action ('Reduce price from $X to $Y'), (2) expected outcome ('cuts conversion time from 30 days to 10 days'), (3) data rationale ('based on 150 comparable listings'). Avoid generic advice like 'Consider adjusting your price.'
scan_order: 1st: Constraint headline ('This price is 20% above comparable properties')
2nd: Specific recommended action ('Reduce from $150 to $125/day')
3rd: Expected outcome ('3x increase in visibility')
4th: Data rationale ('Based on 150 comparable listings in your area')
exclude: Accepting all listings without feedback—silence implies approval
Generic messaging like 'Consider adjusting your price' without specific recommendations
Framing constraint feedback as criticism rather than collaborative optimization
Waiting for hosts to ask for advice—proactive feedback is essential

elements.title: Scarcity Proof Engine: Real-Time Demand Validation
elements.problem: Robert opened with a scarcity frame: 'We have too much demand and not enough inventory' (01:54-02:35). Jessica, a sophisticated operator, recognizes sales tactics. She doesn't blindly accept the scarcity claim; she's testing it conditionally ('I'll send a couple of listings by Friday'). If those test listings don't receive proposals quickly, Jessica will conclude the demand story was oversold, and the partnership will stall. Cialdini: 'newly experienced scarcity is the more powerful kind'—scarcity becomes persuasive when verified through direct experience, not asserted. Current process relies on verbal scarcity claims without providing early proof that validates them. Information architecture challenge: How do we convert scarcity claims into verifiable proof within the host's first week?
elements.solution: Build a 'scarcity proof engine' that converts demand claims into real-time data visible to hosts. Primary layer (within 24 hours of evaluation call): Send 'waitlist snapshot' email: 'Here are 5 active guest searches that match your inventory profile [guest persona, budget range, move-in timeline].' Secondary layer (within 48 hours of listing going live): Send 'listing performance' email: 'Your listing has been viewed by 23 guests. 4 have saved it. We'll notify you as proposals arrive.' Tertiary layer (when proposal arrives): Celebrate velocity: 'Your listing received its first proposal in 4 days! This is faster than average (7-day median). Here's the guest profile for your review.' Information hierarchy: Match demand to host's inventory FIRST (personalized waitlist), then show aggregate engagement metrics SECOND (views, saves), then celebrate conversion velocity THIRD (proposal arrival).

evidence.quote: Robert: 'Right now, the way we operate is if we find we have, unfortunately we have right now too much demand and not enough inventory.'
evidence.insight: Robert uses scarcity framing to position Jessica's inventory as valuable. This is a persuasion tactic, but Jessica doesn't yet have evidence to validate it. She's proceeding cautiously ('I'll send a couple of listings') rather than committing her full portfolio.

evidence.quote: The idea that newly experienced scarcity is the more powerful kind applies to situations well beyond the bounds of the cookie study.
evidence.insight: Cialdini: 'newly experienced scarcity'—scarcity you directly witness—is more persuasive than scarcity that's merely described. Jessica needs to experience demand (proposals arriving for her listings) to believe the scarcity claim is real.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I'll see if I can get a couple [of listings].'
evidence.insight: Jessica commits to 'a couple' of test listings, not her full inventory. This is cautious behavior signaling she's testing Split Lease's demand claims before scaling commitment. If test listings don't convert quickly, she won't send more.

evidence.quote: Staying with the newly scarce cookies now, there was a certain cookie that was the highest rated of all: those that became less available because of a demand for them.
evidence.insight: Cialdini's cookie study: scarcity caused by demand (competition) is more persuasive than scarcity caused by supply limits. If Jessica sees her listings receiving multiple proposals (demand-driven scarcity), she'll prioritize Split Lease over other channels.

evidence.quote: Scarcity Validation Through Early Proof: 'If those test listings don't receive proposals quickly, Jessica will conclude the demand story was oversold. The current process relies on verbal scarcity claims without providing early proof.'
evidence.insight: Layer 1 identified the user goal: 'Verify that Split Lease's demand claims are real by seeing concrete proof within days.' Layer 2 structures this as: personalized waitlist snapshot (PRIMARY, within 24 hours), engagement metrics (SECONDARY, within 48 hours of listing live), conversion celebration (TERTIARY, when proposal arrives).

elements.hierarchy_principle: Personalized demand proof is PRIMARY information (sent within 24 hours of commitment: 'Here are 5 guests searching for your inventory type'). Real-time engagement metrics are SECONDARY (sent within 48 hours of listing going live: 'Your listing has been viewed by X guests'). Conversion velocity celebration is TERTIARY (sent when proposal arrives: 'Faster than average!'). Never rely solely on verbal scarcity claims—hosts need data.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate proof: Within 24 hours of evaluation call, send personalized waitlist snapshot showing guests searching for host's inventory profile. Early validation: Within 48 hours of listing going live, send engagement metrics (views, saves, matched searches). Rapid celebration: When first proposal arrives, send velocity comparison ('4 days vs. 7-day median') to validate demand claim.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Waitlist snapshot: show 5 active guest searches (not more—creates decision paralysis). For each search, show 3 data points: (1) guest persona (young professional, student, family), (2) budget range ($100-$150/day), (3) move-in timeline (within 30 days). Engagement metrics: show 3 numbers: views, saves, matched searches. Conversion celebration: 1 headline (time-to-proposal) + 1 comparison (vs. median).
scan_order: 1st: Demand claim headline ('12 guests on waitlist for your property type')
2nd: Personalized guest search examples (5 active searches with persona/budget/timeline)
3rd: Real-time engagement metrics when listing goes live (views, saves, matches)
4th: Conversion velocity celebration when proposal arrives (time-to-proposal vs. median)
exclude: Relying solely on verbal scarcity claims ('We have too much demand')—hosts recognize this as sales tactic
Waiting for proposals to arrive organically before communicating—send engagement metrics proactively
Generic 'your listing is live' notifications without specific data—provide views, saves, matched searches
Letting test listings languish without follow-up—if no proposals after 7 days, proactively reach out with explanations and recommendations

elements.title: Communication Channel Router: Honor Preference Across Journey
elements.problem: At 18:07, Jessica explicitly states: 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get.' This is critical operational intelligence. If Split Lease sends proposals, listing updates, or guest communications via email (the default channel), Jessica may miss them entirely. She's a busy broker managing multiple deals across multiple channels. Email overload is a real constraint. Missing a guest proposal notification because it arrived via email when she prefers text could cost her a conversion and erode trust. The current process doesn't systematically capture or honor communication channel preferences, leaving hosts to discover through missed messages that the default channel doesn't work for them. Information architecture challenge: How do we ensure time-sensitive information reaches hosts through their preferred channel?
elements.solution: Build a 'communication channel router' that captures preference during onboarding and honors it systematically across all journey phases. Primary layer (first post-call follow-up): Ask explicitly: 'How would you prefer to receive time-sensitive notifications (proposals, guest questions, booking confirmations)? Email, text, or both?' Store preference in host profile. Display prominently in dashboard: 'Notifications: Text preferred (updated 2 days ago).' Secondary layer (notification routing logic): Time-sensitive communications (proposals arriving, guest questions, booking confirmations) → preferred channel. Non-urgent communications (weekly summaries, platform updates) → email by default. Tertiary layer (preference management): Allow hosts to update anytime via dashboard settings. When sending first notification via preferred channel, acknowledge: 'You'll receive this via text, as you requested. Change this anytime in settings.' Information hierarchy: Capture preference FIRST (during onboarding), route consistently SECOND (across all phases), enable easy updates THIRD (dashboard settings).

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get.'
evidence.insight: Jessica explicitly states her communication channel preference and explains why: email overload. This is operational intelligence that Split Lease must capture and honor. If proposals arrive via email and Jessica misses them, she'll blame Split Lease for poor communication, not herself for missing emails.

evidence.quote: Communication Channel Preference Capture: 'If Split Lease sends proposals via email when she prefers text, Jessica may miss them entirely. Missing a guest proposal notification could cost her a conversion and erode trust.'
evidence.insight: Layer 1 identified the user goal: 'Receive time-sensitive information through my preferred channel so I don't miss opportunities.' Layer 2 structures this as: preference capture (PRIMARY, during onboarding), routing logic (SECONDARY, applied to all notifications), preference management (TERTIARY, always editable).

evidence.quote: We like people who are similar to us. Consequently, those who wish to be liked in order to increase our compliance can accomplish that purpose by appearing similar to us in any of a wide variety of ways.
evidence.insight: Honoring Jessica's communication preference is a form of similarity/liking building. By adapting to her workflow (text vs. email), Split Lease demonstrates respect for her constraints, increasing liking and compliance (continued partnership).

elements.hierarchy_principle: Preference capture is PRIMARY information (asked during first post-call follow-up, before onboarding begins). Routing logic is SECONDARY (applied systematically across all journey phases for time-sensitive communications). Preference visibility and editability is TERTIARY (displayed in dashboard, editable anytime). Never assume email is acceptable default—busy professionals have email overload.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Explicit capture: Ask preference during first follow-up ('How would you prefer to receive time-sensitive notifications?'). Persistent visibility: Display current preference prominently in host dashboard ('Notifications: Text preferred'). Acknowledgment: When sending first notification via preferred channel, confirm ('You'll receive this via text, as you requested'). Easy updates: Preference editable anytime via dashboard settings, changes take effect immediately.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Preference capture: offer 3 choices (email, text, both). Don't offer more options (Slack, phone call, etc.) unless host specifically requests. For each notification type, categorize as time-sensitive (use preferred channel) or non-urgent (email default). Dashboard preference display: 1 line ('Notifications: Text preferred'), not buried in settings.
scan_order: 1st: Preference question during onboarding ('How would you prefer to receive time-sensitive notifications?')
2nd: Preference confirmation in dashboard ('Notifications: Text preferred')
3rd: First notification acknowledgment ('You'll receive this via text, as you requested')
4th: Preference edit link in dashboard settings ('Change notification preferences')
exclude: Assuming email is acceptable default without asking—busy professionals have email overload
Sending time-sensitive notifications via non-preferred channel—hosts will miss them
Burying preference settings deep in account configuration—make it prominent and easy to change
Failing to acknowledge preference on first notification—hosts need confirmation that system is honoring their choice

elements.title: Trust Gate Documentation: Confidentiality Assurance Up Front
elements.problem: At 08:42, Jessica states: 'I would need for you to sign something with me, a confidentiality agreement, something, because I have no way of knowing since you're not giving me any of the information of the client.' This demand for legal protection surfaces because Robert hasn't established trust through transparency about how Split Lease protects host relationships. Jessica operates in a high-trust environment where brokers protect their landlord relationships fiercely—if Split Lease bypasses her and contacts her landlords directly, she loses reputation and revenue. Her defensive posture ('I have no way of knowing') signals information asymmetry: she doesn't understand how Split Lease's process protects her interests. Information architecture challenge: How do we proactively address confidentiality concerns before hosts raise them defensively?
elements.solution: Front-load confidentiality assurance as a PRIMARY information layer during evaluation, before onboarding begins. On broker partnership page, include 'How We Protect Your Relationships' section: (1) 'You control all landlord contact. Split Lease never contacts your clients directly.' (2) 'Your dashboard shows exactly who sees your listings and when.' (3) 'Standard confidentiality agreement available for all partnerships.' Include downloadable template confidentiality agreement so brokers can review terms before the evaluation call. During call, agent references this proactively: 'As you saw on our broker partnership page, we protect your landlord relationships. You control all contact, and we're happy to sign a confidentiality agreement with you.' Dashboard design: Show host a 'Relationship Protection' panel listing all parties who have viewed their listings, with timestamps. Information hierarchy: Confidentiality assurance FIRST (on partnership page, before call), template agreement SECOND (downloadable without signup), relationship visibility THIRD (dashboard panel showing who sees what).

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I would need for you to sign something with me, a confidentiality agreement, something, because I have no way of knowing since you're not giving me any of the information of the client.'
evidence.insight: Jessica demands legal protection because Robert hasn't established trust through transparency. She's treating Split Lease as an unknown entity that requires contractual safeguards. This defensive posture could be avoided if confidentiality assurance were provided earlier in the evaluation phase.

evidence.quote: Jessica explains her process: 'The client signs an agreement with me. I contact the landlord directly. The landlord gives me the keys.'
evidence.insight: Jessica operates in a high-trust environment where brokers protect their relationships. She needs to understand that Split Lease's process preserves her role as the primary landlord contact, not bypasses her.

evidence.quote: Consequently, we are trained from birth that obedience to proper authority is right and disobedience is wrong. The essential message fills the parental lessons, the schoolhouse rhymes, stories, and songs of our childhood.
evidence.insight: Jessica operates in a professional context where legal agreements (confidentiality agreements, broker contracts) are authority symbols that establish trust. By providing a template agreement proactively, Split Lease aligns with her professional norms.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I would need for you to sign something with me, a confidentiality agreement.' She demands legal protection because Robert hasn't established trust through authority credentials.
evidence.insight: Layer 1 identified defensive posture due to lack of trust signals. Layer 2 translates this into information architecture: confidentiality assurance must be PRIMARY information (visible before evaluation call), with template agreement as SECONDARY layer (downloadable without signup).

elements.hierarchy_principle: Confidentiality assurance is PRIMARY information on broker partnership page (visible before evaluation call begins). Template confidentiality agreement is SECONDARY (downloadable without signup, reviewable in advance). Dashboard relationship visibility is TERTIARY (always-available reference showing who has accessed listings). Never wait for hosts to request legal protection—address it proactively.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Proactive assurance: Broker partnership page includes 'How We Protect Your Relationships' section with 3 principles (you control landlord contact, full visibility into listing access, standard confidentiality agreement available). Template access: Downloadable confidentiality agreement template available without signup. During call: Agent references this proactively ('As you saw on our partnership page, we're happy to sign a confidentiality agreement'). Dashboard visibility: 'Relationship Protection' panel shows all parties who viewed listings, with timestamps.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Confidentiality assurance section: state 3 principles (not more—cognitive overload). Each principle: 1 sentence, clear and concrete. Template agreement: standard 2-page format, not complex legal document. Dashboard 'Relationship Protection' panel: show up to 10 most recent access events (who, what listing, when), with 'View all' link for full history.
scan_order: 1st: Confidentiality headline on broker partnership page ('How We Protect Your Relationships')
2nd: 3 protection principles (you control contact, full visibility, confidentiality agreement available)
3rd: Downloadable template agreement link
4th: Dashboard 'Relationship Protection' panel showing listing access history
exclude: Waiting for hosts to request confidentiality agreements—address proactively during evaluation
Vague language like 'we respect your relationships'—provide concrete principles and template agreement
Hiding relationship visibility in buried settings—make it prominent in dashboard
Complex legal documents that require lawyer review—use standard 2-page template
